result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both Operating w/ PAC (2nd) and OWI (2nd). The defendant was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (2nd) and the other charge, OWI (2nd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Desiree Joyce Alice Rave was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (2nd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Cash bond on file was applied.  Balance is to be paid as follows:  $50 due on or before 1-2-18 and then $50 is due by the 1st of each month thereafter until paid in full.  Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.
10 days jail is deemed served with credit for 22 days served.

Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.
Must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and a driver safety plan.  You must also comply with any recommendations.
Must submit a DNA sample at the Jackson County Jail and pay the surcharge.

records.addlTxt:
Hearing is recorded:  Defendant appears with counsel James Ritland.  ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  There are no victims in this case.  

She will plea to Count 4 with a 1-bracket reduction on the guidelines with other charges dismissed and read-in.  Court reviews charge with potential penalties.  Count 4 - enters a plea of guilty.  Court reviews the elements.  Defendant confirms prior conviction.  Court performs plea/waiver of rights colloquy with defendant.  Court finds she FVKI enters her plea/waives her rights and finds a factual basis exists.  She is found guilty of Count 4 - PAC 2nd.  Count 3 is dismissed and Counts 1 & 2 are dismissed and read-in.

State recommends a sentence of:  $1429 (35), 10 days jail, 12 mos rev, 12 mos IID, AA & DSP.  Credit of 22 days.  Request cash bond be applied.  Defense makes statement to the court.  

Court adopts the recommendation and orders a fine of $350 plus costs for $1429.  10 days jail with credit for time served of 22 days.  License revocation of 12 months, IID of 12 months.  Cash on file is to be applied.  May pay the remaining balance at $50 per month commencing 1-1-18 with FTP 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.  Alcohol assessment and driver safety plan as condition of reinstatement.  Must submit a DNA sample.
Plea/sentencing hearing on December 13, 2017 at 09:45 am.
Motion to determine admissibility of evidence

Defendant appears with counsel James Ritland.  ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  There is no resolution at this time.  Parties to be ready by 8:30 on trial date.  Ranking should be known by Wednesday this week.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
